Chord Progression:
Am Am C C (“I’ll remember… done”)
Am Am G G (“Can’t she see… one”)

Strange enough at the end of each verse before the bridge, rather than having it end with the A minor like expected, it ends with a C major to go into A minor. The progression ends with a classic G major to go back to C major (V to I) in the beginning of the next verse.

Key: C major
Chord Progression:
C F (2x, “I’m… guy,” “Never… cry”)
F G C a (“The world… misery”)
C F (2x, “I’ve… sure,” “I won’t… more”)
F G C C (“It’s going… misery”)

While the progression is generic for the most part, the only twist is the inclusion of A minor (a) at the end of “misery.” One would think the phrase would end by sticking to the root chord (C major), but instead they utilize A minor to go back to C when the progression repeats again with “I’ve lost her now for sure.” The progression is also the same for all remaining verses.

The other funny fact is the key. C major is normally reserved for pure and happy songs, but here it’s being used for a breakup tune.

The leading piano arpeggio plays out an F major chord:
F-C-F-A-C-F (from lowest octave to highest octave, in that order)

On “bad” comes G major, and on “misery” the chord is C major. Lennon and McCartney harmonize as such:
D-E-E (McCartney, higher part)
B-C-C (Lennon, lower part)

B and D implies the aforementioned G major chord (G, B, and D are the notes), while C and E implies the C major chord (C, E, and G). After this follows two chords, A minor and G major again, which leads into C major for the beginning of the first verse.

The Beatles' version of this song is completely, unremarkably typical of their early pop releases, particularly in the joint lead vocal style of Lennon and McCartney. McCartney only breaks from Lennon’s lead melody for singular words in the chorus, which was likely his biggest contribution to the composition of this song.

Kenny Lynch actually attempted to co-write a song on the Helen Shapiro tour with Lennon-McCartney, but became frustrated with them at their inability to communicate with him and stormed off. The song this writing session would come to produce? From Me To You.

This song features piano by George Martin, who recorded it half an octave lower and half as fast as it can be heard on the record. Preferring to record the original song with the tapes running at double speed (30ips) allowed him to do this, and it was a practice used by The Beatles and Martin several times in their studio albums. Another notable use is in the piano solo of Lovely Rita.
